details.title: Discriminating Among the Log-Normal, Weibull, and Generalized Exponential Distributions
details.standardTitle: Discriminating Among the Log-Normal, Weibull, and Generalized Exponential Distributions

p: Arabin Kumar Dey is a Research Scholar at the Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur. He received his B.Sc., and M.Sc. degrees from the University of Calcutta, India in 2001, and 2003 respectively. He was awarded a Junior Research fellowship in 2004, and then a Senior Research fellowship in 2006 By the Council of Scientific and Industrial Research, Government of India. His current research interests center on model discrimination, reliability, survival analysis, asymptotics, and statistical computing.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Math. & Stat., Indian Inst. of Technol. Kanpur, Kanpur, India
authors.name: Arabin Kumar Dey

p: Debasis Kundu is a USV Chair Professor in the Department of Mathematics and Statistics at the Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur. He received the B.Stat. in 1982, and M.Stat. in 1984, both from the Indian Statistical Institute; a M.A. (Mathematics) in 1985 from the University of Pittsburgh; and the Ph.D. in 1989 from the Pennsylvania State University. He is a Fellow of the National Academy of Sciences India. He is on the editorial boards of Communications in Statistics—Theory and Methods, Communications in Statistics—Simulation and Computation, Journal of Statistical Theory, and Journal of Modern Applied Statistical Methods. His research interests include statistical signal processing, reliability analysis, competing risks models, and distribution theory. He has more than 140 publications in different peer reviewed journals.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Math. & Stat., Indian Inst. of Technol. Kanpur, Kanpur, India
authors.name: Debasis Kundu

details.abstract: We consider model selection and discrimination among three important lifetime distributions. These three distributions have been used quite effectively to analyze lifetime data. We study the probability of correct selection using the maximized likelihood method, as it has been used in the literature. We further compute the asymptotic probability of correct selection, and compare the theoretical, and simulation results for different sample sizes, and for different model parameters. The results have been extended for Type-I censored data also. The theoretical, and simulation results match quite well. Two real data sets have been analyzed for illustrative purposes. We also suggest a method to determine the minimum sample size required to discriminate among the three distributions for a given probability of correct selection, and a user specified protection level.

context.text: Due to increasing applications of the lifetime distributions, special attention has been paid in discriminating between the log-normal, and Weibull distributions (Dumonceaux & Antle [7], Pereira [19], Chen [4], Quesenberry & Kent [23], Kundu & Manglick [13], Pascual [18]); the gamma, and Weibull distributions (Bain & Englehardt [2], Fearn & Nebenzahl [8]); the gamma, and log-normal distributions (Kundu & Manglick [14]); the log-normal, and GE distributions (Kundu & Gupta & Manglick [12]); and the Weibull, and GE distributions (Gupta & Kundu [9]).

For example, let us compare the PCS between GE and Weibull (Gupta & Kundu [9]), and GE and log-normal (Kundu & Gupta & Manglick [12]), when the data are from GE distribution, and when the shape parameter of the GE distribution is 2.0.
We do not want to discriminate between two distribution functions if the distance between them is less than the tolerance level [9].
Here we use the K-S distance as a measure of distance between two distributions, similarly as in Gupta & Kundu [9].
